bestBHT.bht: A young man, dressed in a linen cloth, followed Jesus. This cloth, a fine linen often used for wrapping the dead, was possibly a sheet or shirt. Filled with fear, the young man left the linen cloth behind and ran away naked, similar to Joseph leaving his garment when escaping from his mistress. The words from them can be excluded, as some versions do. This incident showcases how even small details can hold symbolic significance and enrich the biblical narrative.

Philip Schaff: Mark 14:52. Naked. Bengel says: ‘Modesty was overcome by fear in this great danger.’ The words ‘from them’ are to be omitted.
Archibald T. Robertson: Linen cloth (σινδονα). An old Greek word of unknown origin.
It was fine linen cloth used often for wrapping the dead.
In this instance it could have been a fine sheet or even a shirt.
John Gill: And he left the linen cloth.... just as Joseph left his garment in the hands of his mistress.
and fled from them naked; to the house from whence he came.
The Syriac, Arabic, Persic, and Ethiopic versions, leave out the words 'from them'.

This linen cloth may have been a fine sheet or even a shirt. The words from them in the verse can be omitted, as the Syriac, Arabic, Persic, and Ethiopic versions do. This incident highlights how even a seemingly insignificant detail can provide deeper symbolism and meaning within the biblical narrative.
